M.G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to M.G.L. c. 185C, § 20, which governs proceedings relating to landlord-tenant disputes in Massachusetts District Courts.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in **Somerville District Court** pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address ongoing noise violations has effectively deprived Plaintiff of the quiet enjoyment of her premises in violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, which prohibits landlords from taking or failing to take actions that substantially interfere with a tenant's ability to use and enjoy their property.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a statutory and common-law duty on landlords to ensure their tenants’ ability to use and enjoy their leased premises free from substantial interference. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses both the statutory quiet enjoyment remedy under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, describing the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. It holds that the landlord had a duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions and that repeated flooding interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, thus recognizing both statutory and common-law duties to protect the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises from substantial interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a statutory and common-law duty on landlords to ensure their tenants’ ability to use and enjoy their leased premises free from substantial interference. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly characterizes the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of their premises and applies that principle to hold that tenants may recover when the landlord’s omissions allow such substantial interference. While framed through G.L. c. 186, § 14 rather than “landlords” in general, the court clearly affirms that Massachusetts law (statutory quiet enjoyment and its common‑law understanding via Simon v. Solomon) imposes a duty on landlords to avoid conduct or omissions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment of leased premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when their actions or omissions “interfere substantially” with the tenant’s use of the premises.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability and the interaction between sanitary/building codes and rent obligations. It does not interpret or apply M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment or define breach in terms of “substantial interference.” Accordingly, this part of Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway does not provide authority for the claimed proposition under c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The opinion of the court in the present cases does not discuss or otherwise deal with the rule quoted above from Palmigiani v. D’Argento... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards...

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: The substantial interference suffered by Plaintiff has caused her discomfort, loss of sleep, and financial injury, all of which constitute compensable damages as established in Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997) and Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638 N.E.2d 923 (Mass. App. Ct. 1994).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis concerns whether violation of the lead paint statute, without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and thus supports an award of attorney’s fees. The opinion does not discuss the categories or measure of compensable damages such as discomfort, loss of sleep, or financial injury; it simply notes that the jury awarded compensatory damages for lead poisoning and addresses only the legal standard for liability and fee-shifting under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific damages proposition claimed.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “In response to special questions, the jury found that lead paint on the premises was the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries, and awarded $25,000 in compensatory damages to Dina and $10,000 in compensatory damages to Husam.… The only question is whether on this record the plaintiffs were entitled to recover attorney’s fees under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638.raw_text: Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638 N.E.2d 923 (Mass. App. Ct. 1994)
Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638.proposition: The substantial interference suffered by Plaintiff has caused her discomfort, loss of sleep, and financial injury, all of which constitute compensable damages as established in Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997) and Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638 N.E.2d 923 (Mass. App. Ct. 1994).
Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether the Attorney General qualifies as an “aggrieved person” entitled to attorney’s fees under the Massachusetts anti‑discrimination housing statute. It does not discuss the nature or scope of compensable damages such as discomfort, loss of sleep, or financial injury, nor does it analyze what kinds of harms are recoverable. The only mention of damages is a bare statement that the complainant was awarded $1,000, without any elaboration of the categories of injury, so it does not support the specific damages proposition cited.
Roslindale Coop. Bank v. Greenwald, 638.relevant_excerpt: “A judge of that court found that the Dowds had, indeed, violated § 4(7), enjoined them from further violation, and awarded compensatory damages of $1,000 to Lois Vance, the woman to whom Florence Dowd in September, 1989, had refused to lease an apartment because Vance proposed to occupy it with a man friend.”

Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 925 (1983)
Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. C.proposition: Each instance in which Defendant failed to act constitutes a separate and distinct violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, as held in Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 925 (1983).
Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns criminal convictions for assault with a dangerous weapon and related issues of prosecutorial argument and disclosure of police reports. It does not mention landlord-tenant law, M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, or the concept that each failure to act constitutes a separate statutory violation. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition claimed and appears to be miscited or entirely inapposite to that proposition.
Dolben Co. v. Friedberg, 15 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt:
The defendant was convicted by a jury on indictments charging him with assault by means of a dangerous weapon, carrying a firearm without a license, unlawful possession of ammunition, and receiving stolen property.
...
2. For the reasons given by the trial judge in her memorandum on the defendant’s motion for a new trial, she was not in error in concluding that the defendant was not prejudiced by the failure of the Commonwealth to turn over Lake’s arrest report to the defendant.

Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 215 (201.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover actual damages or three times the monthly rent, whichever is greater, in addition to attorneys’ fees and costs. See Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 215 (2016).
Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 215 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion in Meikle v. Nurse is about whether a violation of the security deposit statute (G.L. c. 186, § 15B) can be asserted as a defense to possession under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does mention that the security deposit statute provides for treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, but it does not construe G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it state the specific measure of damages under § 14 (actual damages or three times the monthly rent, whichever is greater). Therefore, it does not support the specific damages proposition attributed to it under § 14.
Meikle v. Nurse, 474 Mass. 207, 215 (201.relevant_excerpt: “Indeed, the security deposit statute has no raison d’etre other than to insure fairness to a tenant who pays a sum to the landlord and relies on the landlord’s good faith for the return of the portion to which he or she is entitled at the end of the tenancy. … Indeed, the security deposit statute provides for treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 15B (7).”
